an6.13:1.1: “Mendicants, there are these six elements of escape.
an6.13:1.4: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by love. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.
an6.13:1.5: Yet somehow ill will still occupies my mind.’
an6.13:1.6: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.
an6.13:1.7: It’s impossible, reverend, it cannot happen that the heart’s release by love has been developed and properly implemented,
an6.13:1.8: yet somehow ill will still occupies the mind.
an6.13:1.9: For it is the heart’s release by love that is the escape from ill will.’
an6.13:2.2: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by compassion. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.
an6.13:2.3: Yet somehow the thought of harming still occupies my mind.’
an6.13:2.4: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …
an6.13:2.7: For it is the heart’s release by compassion that is the escape from thoughts of harming.’
an6.13:3.2: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by rejoicing. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.
an6.13:3.3: Yet somehow discontent still occupies my mind.’
an6.13:3.4: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …
an6.13:3.7: For it is the heart’s release by rejoicing that is the escape from discontent.’
an6.13:4.2: ‘I’ve developed the heart’s release by equanimity. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.
an6.13:4.3: Yet somehow desire still occupies my mind.’
an6.13:4.4: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …
an6.13:4.7: For it is the heart’s release by equanimity that is the escape from desire.’
an6.13:5.2: ‘I’ve developed the signless release of the heart. I’ve cultivated it, made it my vehicle and my basis, kept it up, consolidated it, and properly implemented it.
an6.13:5.3: Yet somehow my consciousness still follows after signs.’
an6.13:5.4: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! …
an6.13:5.7: For it is the signless release of the heart that is the escape from all signs.’
an6.13:6.2: ‘I’m rid of the conceit “I am”. And I don’t regard anything as “I am this”.
an6.13:6.3: Yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupies my mind.’
an6.13:6.4: They should be told, ‘Not so, venerable! Don’t say that. Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.
an6.13:6.5: It’s impossible, reverend, it cannot happen that the conceit “I am” has been done away with, and nothing is regarded as “I am this”,
an6.13:6.6: yet somehow the dart of doubt and indecision still occupies the mind.
an6.13:6.7: For it is the uprooting of the conceit “I am” that is the escape from the dart of doubt and indecision.’
an6.13:7.1: These are the six elements of escape.”
